Well, you almost got it. Helicopter blades is not a gyroscope. A gyroscope is a device that has a rotating mass, that is isolated from any external change in orientation.

Every other example where mass is made to rotate, is not a gyroscope, but only a rotating mass that can exhibit gyroscopic force. Gyroscopic force has two fundamental behaviors, the classical “ stabile” reaction, and “ unstable” which is the most common reaction but is not generally understood by many .

If any rotating mass is not held in isolation from external changes in orientation, it will exhibit the second behavioral nature of gyroscopic force, which is unstable.

Land speed car wheels, because a vehicle can yaw, exhibits unstable gyroscopic force ,( gyroscopic precession torque). .wheels and helicopter blades are not gyroscopes.
The early ones started out being called gyros.

The 90 deg phase on a swash plate is a control input, not a force.
GP requires a force acting on the axis of the spinning disc. If you watch a spinning bike wheel the force twists the axis (axle hub), creating GP at 90 deg to the force.
The 90 deg control input of the swash plate is NOT forcing the rotor shaft (axle hub) to move. Rather the 90 deg phase lag is to move the blade pitch to make them to fly up/down as it rotates (cyclic control).
However, if the control input was to twist the main shaft back and forth, then GP would be present since it is applying a force to twist the axis.
Try this in a vacuum. Swash plate control inputs would have no effect since the blades have no air to fly up/down in. Yet if the inputs twist the rotor shaft then you would see the disc move in accordance with GP.
I agree that GP is present in the system, but not to control it. It is a by product of the effects of cyclic inputs.

An easy, no-math explanation: The only principle you need is that a particle tends to move in the direction of the applied force.
For reference, refer to 4:35. The wheel is spinning clockwise when viewed from the top. For ease of explanation, imagine a clock face superimposed on the wheel so that 12 o'clock is the most distant point of the wheel and 6 o'clock is closest to the guy's chin.
Now suppose a point on the wheel is passing through the 6 o'clock position. The guy pushes upward on the lever. This tends to make the point on the wheel move straight up. However, because the wheel is spinning, the point does not move straight up - it sort of goes on an incline, up and to the left. It will continue up this incline until it reaches a maximum Up at the 9 o'clock position. At this point, the force applied by spokes tends to win out and the point begins to move downward and to the right, on a downward incline.
It will continue on this downward incline until it reaches the 9 o'clock position where the spokes again win out and starts the point moving upward again. So what do we have? Maximum Up occurs at 9 o'clock. Maximum Down occurs at 3 o'clock. The only way this can happen is for the plane of the wheel to tilt to the right, as you can observe in the video.
For fun, suppose the wheel was rotating in the opposite direction. Push the lever up as before. Now the point (at 6 o'clock) will begin to travel on an upward incline to the right. Where will it reach the maximum Up? And, of course, the plane of the wheel will tilt to the left.
What if the wheel were not rotating at all? In this case, the point would simply move straight up without traveling on an incline, and there would be no precession.
Not so hard after all, is it? :) (10/2020)

The principle is simple. Imagine a car is running towards the east and it will go around the earth on the equator. When it is in Singapore, you give it a force towards the north, and then the new route will deviate from the equator. But the most northern point on the new route is not Singapore. If the new route is a circle so the car gets Singapore after 360 degrees, the most northern point will be at somewhere 90 degrees east Singapore. This is what the propeller does.

Picture a bug crawling around, and around, on the equator of a clear ball.  The bug takes the same path all the time, and to the bug, it's going in a straight line.  In fact, that bug only wants to walk in a straight line.  Now, give the bug a shove to the side of his head to send him off of his old track by a few degrees.  He walks off in a straight line around the surface of the ball following the new course you set for him.  You will notice that he will come back to the exact spot where you interfered with him, and he'll keep going on this new path, and returning to that same spot every time.  Picture yourself being the bug, your course is changed, and a mark is put on the ball where it happened.  You walk 1/2 way around the ball, and you see that you are exactly opposite the point where your course was changed.  You also notice that you are crossing your old route at that spot too.   The points where your new path are the furthest from your old path, are 90 degrees apart from the point where your course changed.

The bicycle wheel demo shows that it happens, but doesn't describe why. The reason is easy to visualise when the solid wheel is replaced with a wheel of flexible blades with weights on the ends. It's difficult to describe in words, but really easy to see. Surprisingly, I can't find a YouTube video of it. I saw it once in one of the Christmas lectures on TV - and immediately grasped how gyroscopic precession works.
Basically, it's Newton's first law - every object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change its state by the action of an external force. Thinking of the flexible blades model, the blades fly around in what we will call the reference disc. When the hub is rocked towards you, there is a tendency to rock the plane of the blades towards you also, with the lowest part of the disc closest to you - but it doesn't happen immediately. The blade at 3-o-clock would go to 6-0-clock (in the reference plane) unless acted on by a force - but there is a force - the hub has been rocked downwards. However, the blade doesn't feel that force at all when it is at 3-o-clock - it feels it at a maximum when it is at 6-o-clock, and starts to move downwards below the reference plane. As it proceeds towards the 9-o-clock position, it continues to move downward, but at 9-o-clock, it feels a force moving it up above the reference disc. It starts to move up at that point, so its momentum is moving from 'going down' to 'gpoing up'. You can see that its maximum "down" point is at 9-o-clock, although you rocked the disc towards you, so the lowest point should be 6-o-clock. When the blades are at their lowest point (9-o-clock) they will exert the maximum force on the hub - and that's why the maximum force is at 90-degrees to the angle of rocking.
It just goes to show - gyroscopes rock - man!

Not that I've read every comment, but I see a lot of "rules" but no "why". Here's my best guess: The force applied to one end of a spinning disk imparts inertia to a point on the disk. As that point spins to the opposite side of the disk, it counteracts itself exactly 180 degrees out. IE: The "same" amount of force is applied to both sides of the axle/fulcrum causing zero angular force. However, assuming the initial force was downward, at 90 degrees from the initial force there would be residual downward inertia, while ate 270 degrees the residual inertia from the opposite side would be upward because the original force, applied against the disc and against the fulcrum/axle caused upward inertia on the opposite side. In other words, the inertia at 0 and 180 degrees cancel each other out while the inertia at 90 and 270 degrees is complimentary. Does this make any sense to anybody? :)

i emailed you on this topic before because your explanation is partially correct however your missing 2 key points (you never replied to me). I teach this topic to engineering students and have come quite fond of the discussion this inevitability creates.
the term 'Gyroscopic Precession' when in the Helicopter world has 2 functions to it
A) the 90 deg out of phase force effect due to the normal meaning of the word Gyroscopic Precession', and,
B) a 90 deg aerodynamic out of phase effect to provide true directional control via the cyclic.
Lets discuss deeper but do it B) first then A). also naming convention used here in 12 o'clock =forward, 6 o'clock rear, 3 o'clock pilots right hand side and therefore 9 o'clock is the pilots left hand side.
B) to move the helicopter in the forward 12 o'clock direction we DO NOT have a higher lift production at the rear (6 o'clock) of the disc but rather wee have the blade at the 6 o'clock position flying higher (relative to the POR, plane of rotation of the disk). that way the total reaction of all the blades is forward of the mast axis. meaning the 12 o'clock blade lift force if vertical and the 6 o'clock blade's lift force is not vertical any more it is forward of vertical.. the question is HOW do we get the rear blade to fly higher than the rest or cone up more than the rest when the pilot pushes forward on the cyclic.... see A)
A) the nature of the out of phase control linkage between the cyclic, scissor levers, control rods, pitch horns on the blade grips and the location of the pitch horns are not this way by accident (obviously) rather are there because of the two factors discussed here in.
A1) the aerodynamic part of the gyroscopic precession feature (not correctly used term but non the less a important factor). i need the blade to fly high at the rear of the disk if i want to fly forward however it takes some time to alter the path of the rotating blade so i need to tell it to fly high when the blade is at the 3 o'clock position. Thus the blade at the 3 o'clock position has the highest blade pitch input because we need the blade to be lifted up to a higher tip path to generate the forward facing life force when it becomes at the 6 o'clock position.
A2) knowing that i need to provide a mechanical input force to the blade pitch change point/axis and knowing that true gyroscopic precession exists with this large rotating mass i need to apply that 'up force' to the pitch change control rod (swash-plate to pitch horn on the blade grip) when the blade is 90 deg before the required up force. thus i push up on the control rod at the 3 o'clock position.

NETT RESULT
to fly forward i use an aerodynamic 'gyroscopic' effect coupled with the try gyroscopic effect of the rotating mass of the blades and the disk.

NOTE; the term aerodynamic gyroscopic effect has nothing to do with the mass of the object rather a out of phase delay that happens.

Hey Dustin,

Believe it or not, steering a motorcycle at speed uses the exact same principle.

At near walking speeds, it is as simple as turning the handlebars in the direction you want to turn.

But, at speed, you have to push on the handlebars in the direction you want to turn.

Push left to lean left to turn left.

Push right to lean right to turn right.

It sounds rather cerebral, but even bicycling at faster speeds, you use the same technique. The result is that it becomes second nature and you do it without thinking about it.

Hi, I enjoyed your video but sorry to say you have misunderstood what is happening. All helicopters have flapping hinges or either flexible blades or blade roots that allow the blades to flap up and down. Without, as speed increased there would be uncontrollable rolling moments. I know this is an old video, don't know if you'll get this... I never knew this about helicopter controls, but as you described gyroscopic procession, it reminded me of a real-world example I experienced 20+ years ago.

If you've ever been in a building with really big, shiny floors, you might have seen a buffing machine - the Army uses them in barracks, janitors use them in schools...

As it happens, unsupervised youths - as I was at the time - occasionally try to ride these things - as I did at the time...

The physics may very well be different from what you describe, but the effect is the same: to go forward, you lean to the side. You travel on tangent to the spinning disc, at the point where your weight is creating the most friction with the floor. So if the disc is spinning clockwise, then at the front of the disc the tangent points right; to your right the tangent points back; behind you the tangent points left, and to your left the tangent points forward. I imagined it like the point where I leaned is like a canoe paddle. So to go forward, lean right - the disc digs in pushing backward, and the buffer and rider are pushed forward.

You explained gyroscopic precession but did not explain WHY THIS HAPPENS! I am a flight instructor and hopefully this will give you all an insight. It's going to be super hard to explain without a visual but I'll try lol. Think about a ball rolling from left to right (west to east) in a straight line. While the ball is rolling, you gently tap the ball directly towards the north. The resultant force will take the ball north east. Same thing with the wheel. As the  wheel is spinning counter clockwise (west to east), you push the wheel up and the resultant force will be towards the north east causing the entire wheel to point in that direction. You will see it roll to the left. Hence gyroscopic precession. Ik this is super confusing but I hope some of you understood it.

All sounds correct. But, there is one final twist. The compensation for the 90 degree delay is built-in on the attachment point between blade and control rod. And the attachment point is 90 degrees ahead of the blade's leading edge. The end result is that when the swash plate tilts straight forward, the copter flies straight forward. To fully understand what is going on, you need to explain the feather shaft that is hidden from any view.

My best explanation is relatively simple, I don't know if it makes sense but it works:
Imagine vectors of momentum (not angular momentum) of small parts of the spinning wheel (in this example - horizontal and clockwise from above). Now you apply the force (vertical, it acts "upwards" on the side where the metal stick is and "downwards" on the other). As the force is change of momentum in time you can add these two vectors of momentum (one is horizontal, second is vertical) and here you are - new vectors are not horizontal but somewhat diagonal and thus - sideway tilt (to the right from perspective of person applying the force).

I love your work. I’d just like to add that aerodynamic forces also play a role, contributing to the gyroscopic effect on the plane of rotation of the rotor “disk”. Let’s consider a 2-blade teetering-rotor American helicopter (where the blades rotate clockwise when viewed from below). Let’s keep it simple and say there is nil wind and the rotorcraft is in the hover, with the rotor disk level and parallel to the ground. The pilot wishes to accelerate the a/c forward. You are correct that a pitch increase must be applied to the retreating blade (and a pitch decrease to the advancing blade), when each of these blades are athwartships - i.e. 90 degrees before the desired effect. However, this pitch change cannot physically have an instantaneous effect – rather, it causes the tip-path of the retreating blade to start climbing and that of the advancing blade to start descending. The net result is that the advancing blade tip-path reaches its lowest point at the front of the a/c and the retreating blade reaches its highest point at the rear of the a/c, so that the rotor “disk” (tip-path plane) is tilted forward.

So... I disagree with this.
Gyroscopic procession is what you get when you try to tilt a rotating disk by applying tilting force to the rotating axis. Helicopters work backwards to this. The disk itself is what is applying the tilting force to the rotating axis.

The helicopter disk is flying, like a wing, through the air and its lift is controlled by the pitch angle you give it. via the swash plate.

The rotating disk is actually what is applying the tilting force to the main shaft. The only thing the swash plate does is change the pitch of the blades. This part is the important part....The blades are wings and follow the pitch angle. Tilt them up, and they rise, tilt them down, and they sink.
To make the back of the disk go up, (forward movement) you tilt the swash plate forward. This changes the pitch of the blade at 90 degrees.... Actually it changes it not just at the 90 deg position, but around the entire rotation of the blades. It is just most visible at the 90 degree position. The pitch is flat at the front and back because the blade has lifted as high as its going to go and needs to immediately start flying down to be low at the front.

The idea you have to wrap your brain around, is the disk is tilting itself. Zero force is being applied to the gyroscopic disks axle, therefore, no gyroscopic procession.

However, There can be gyroscopic procession that happens in a helicopter. If an outside force tries to tilt the rotor by means of tilting the whole helicopter, for example, say someone lifts the tail upward. at this point, the shaft is tilting forward and trying to tilt the disk, and THAT induces Gyroscopic procession. A common occurrence of this is when wind starts to push a helicopter sideways when landing. The helicopter can slide sideways along the ground until the skids grip the ground or worse if the hit something that stops them from sliding. The momentum causes the helicopter to tilt sideways which induces forward or backward tilt gyroscopic procession.

The same principle is used by (advanced) motorcyclists who need to swerve quickly.  If you tap the right handle bar forward while traveling, the bike will roll sharply to the right, allowing a sharp right swerve.  (The front wheel turns slightly to the left for a moment, but the roll to the right is much more significant.  So, you turn the wheel slightly to the left to swerve to the right.)  It's counter-intuitive, but it works.

This gyroscopic rule applies in varying amounts in various rotor systems. In rigid rotor systems the phase is not 90 degrees, and in a fully teetering system, there is for all intents no precession at all. The blades fly up and down as they travel through 360 degrees and the angle of the rotor plane changes, thereby altering the thrust line. the rotor cannot change the angle of the fuselage directly, because the teetering hinge does not allow it; it simply averages the lift difference between the two rotor blades. This precession explanation was a simplistic but incorrect way to describe aerodynamic precession in the early days of teetering rotor systems. This video helps you grasp the concept of phase angle, but little else.

While your explanation is technically correct the explanation as relates to the model bring used (that of an Apache helicopter) is actually 180 degrees out for any American made helicopter. By that I mean that since with all American helicopters the rotor system spins counterclockwise (as seen from above) the increase in pitch to cause the helicopter to tile (move) forward is applied on the left side of the aircraft, not on the right. For European-built helicopters, the increase in pitch would be on the right side as as was indicated when the model was used.  In both cases, of course, the pilot simply moves the cyclic in the direction he/she desires to go and the linkage to the rotor system's swashplate takes care of the rest.

This is the resulting lift generated by the rotor blade not achieve the required amount to displace the rotor disk until it is bout 90 degrees from the original input. To combat this the cyclic control is mechanically manipulated to make the pilots inputs reflect the aircrafts attitude.

Destin, first off I want to thank you for a wonderful channel.  My kids homeschool and on their "breaks" we let them watch your shows.  We're effectively tricking them into learning when they think they're playing.  Nice :)

However, I think you may have made an error in describing the physics of helicopter flight.  While helicopter control inputs closely approximate gyroscopic precession (GP), GP is not the reason for the pre-phase of helicopter control inputs.  To see this in action, look at videos of helicopter operations on ships in rough seas.  The rotor disc remains in plane with the ship's deck.  A strictly gyroscopic system would remain in it's original plane.  This is because the primary forces that dictate rotor disc orientation are aerodynamic.  What is really occurring with regard to the difference in swashplate control input and maximum rotor disc deflection is called aerodynamic phase lag.  It is due to the time it takes to accelerate the blade up or down from the point the control input occurs.  It also isn't always 90 degrees.  Depending on rotor RPM it can occur anywhere between about 70 and 90 degrees.  So, while GP is a natural phenomenon that is helpful in demonstrating helicopter aerodynamic characteristics, it is important to note that they are not the same phenomena.  As a side note: The US Army actually teaches that GP is the reason for phase lag, not an approximation, so it's not an uncommon error.

It is not the direction the rotor blade is pointing, it is the direction that the tip of the rotor blade is travelling. If the tip of the rotor blade is travelling towards the back of the helicopter, then lift at that point will raise the back of the helicopter. So if the rotor is spinning clockwise (viewpoint from above), then the tip will be travelling towards the back when it is 90 degrees counterclockwise. The key is to think about the direction the tip of the rotor blade is travelling, not where it is pointing. They are always 90 degrees apart.

Think about a spinning wheel, and split its vectors into four parts. Consider what changing the angle does to the vector of each part. Let's say it's horizontal, and you are south of it, facing north.

So rolling the wheel clockwise makes each section have the following additional motion it previously did not:

North + East - Upwards
North + West - Upwards
South + West - Downwards
South + East - Downwards

The motion of a wheel is 90 degrees in respect to its position. And motion is what counts.

Angular momentum and torque are cross product vector quantities.  effects are orthogonal using the right hand rule.  Cross product vector quantities are involved in electricity and magnetism as well.

When the blade is not turning, The previous angular momentum vector is zero and your delta starts a rotation forward or back (pitching the axis itself) and then stops the rotation.  once you have a non-zero angular momentum, right hand effects show when the torque is not in the direction of the rotation.

As torque and angular momentum are a cross product quantities (as compared to dot products) changes in the total angular moment of the system are dependent on the right hand rule.  This is why the change to the angular momentum vector are orthogonal to the applied torque.

From that point on the advancing blade becomes the retreating blade which is accelerated upwards for forward stick input. It again reaches it's highest position relative to the helicopter body on the very aft position. So downwards acceleration of the advancing blade and upwards acceleration of the retreting blade will cause the rotor disk to be tilted forward relative to the helicopter body. this forward tilt is transfered to the body via the pitch hinge dampening.

Gyroscopic precession seems to be the obvious reason for the position of maximum cyclic pitch being 90° out of phase, but it's in fact not the case. The real reason is the pitch hinges (or blade flex in a model helicopter) that causes the phase difference. For example in case of forward stick input the advancing blade is being accelerated downward. That's the blade, not the whole helicopter because of the pitch hinge. It's got its lowest position right in front of the helicopter.

To try to answer question 1...
From an big-picture conservation of L perspective:
Something initially had L in y-direction. 
A application of the force in x-direction to off-set the gyroscopic axis will still act in x-dir. But doing so tilts the spinning axis. This introduces L in the x-dir (think of L is broken up into Lx and Ly). x-dir initially had Lx = 0. But now has Lx = c. To conserve L, the entire body rof the object rotate along x-axis with Lx = (-1)c (resembling a force in y-dir)

There is a much simpler an intuitive way to understand gyroscopic precession.   Tie a ball to the end of a string or rope and swing it around your head.    Now figure out at what point in the arc you have to apply a force to the ball to cause it to rise or fall directly in front of you.     It's 90 degrees out of phase because the force only changes the direction of the balls travel, which doesn't reach full effect until 90 degrees later.

An impulse is a change of momentum and an impulse is a force integrated over time. (Linear: 𝐏₁ = 𝐏₀+∆𝐏 = 𝐏₀+∫𝐅.dt, Rotational: 𝐋₁ = 𝐋₀+∆𝐋 = 𝐋₀+∫𝛕.dt where 𝐋 is angular momentum, a pseudovector and 𝛕 is torque, another pseudovector). 𝛕 = 𝐫⨯𝐅 where 𝐫 is the displacement from a pivot and ⨯ is cross product. Here, 𝐋₀ is down, 𝐫 is right, 𝐅 is up so 𝛕 and ∆𝐋 are towards the viewer so 𝐋’s tip (which was down) is dragged that way too, so the wheel’s top tips away from the viewer.

The change to a linear momentum vector by a rotational impulse (torque integrated over time) occurs in the obvious mathematical way whatever the rotor speed, though the visually understood effect is a little mind-bending. At rest or at very low RPM, the applied torque vector’s direction dominates the axis of the observed rotation of the spin axis. At high RPM, where 𝐋 is long, the deflection of the spin axis is dominant. Both are 𝐋₁ = 𝐋₀+∆𝐋 = 𝐋₀+∫𝛕.dt = 𝐋₁ = 𝐋₀+∆𝐋 = 𝐋₀+∫(𝐫⨯𝐅).dt.

The phase (direction of precession) approaches 90 degrees in a proportion to how fast the mass is rotating and how much force is applied. In particular the angular acceleration of the precession = the angular acceleration of the spinning plus crossed with the angular acceleration of the due to the force. 

If you think of the initial force as accelerating one blade, that blade gets spun around before it can move very far in the direction it is pushed so its momentum carries it in a new direction

Speed of rotation and rigidity of blades do matter. This is why some R.C. helicopters have a 45 or even 30 degree stabilizer bar phase angle. Rigid blade R.C.'s with 1800 + rpm head speed behave as a disk and work best with 90 degree phasing. Any disk rotating a sufficient rpm to have a gyroscopic effect will react at 90 degrees out of phase. Soft blades rotating at slower speeds do not behave as a disk.

If you apply hard brake in a turn, and you're leaning over, the motorcycle will seek the vertical again straight away, and you will run off the road in a straight line! So when entering a turn, you must choose your line, not go in too hot, (ie. do all your main braking before a turn begins), be cautious with acellerator, and come off throttle if required, lean and counter-steer harder to make the turn, avoid the brake, and only very lightly if required. Countersteering an entire subject, itself.

As long as the wheels are rotating, they are acting as gyroscopes. The effect is to 'right' the motorcycle, and make it stand upright while moving. This is why you have to apply a lot of sideways effort by leaning, to lean the motorcycle over as it WANTS (for a better word) to stabilize by going upright again by itself. The most important thing here to remember, is that braking will make the motorcycle go vertical. This is extremely important in a turn.

A moving bullet falls at the same rate as a stationary bullet, but if you try to change its direction, it takes a lot of force. Imagine a disk made of an infinite number of tiny bullets, whizzing around on stiff wires. When you try to tilt the disk forward, the bullets fore and aft move like the falling bullet, but the bullets to the side have to change direction. One side is deflected up, the other down. Thus, the reaction forces are at 90 degrees to a torque applied to the disk's axis.

Not silly at all. It all comes down to whether or not you are changing the axis of rotation.

To rotate it in a direction it IS spinning would be to keep the plate horizontal and rotate it either clockwise or counter-clockwise. Or in other words it doesn't change the direction the cup is pointing. Look up the wikipedia article on Precession and the HyperPhysics page both have good illustrations about this phenomenon.

As for the terminology, take your plate and place a cup in the center, the cup is pointing upwards. This is the moment of inertia. When you tilt the plate to the left (without letting the cup slide) the cup is now pointing to the left of where it was when the plate was flat. To make this happen you applied a downward force to the left side of the plate which is the same as applied a force to left on the top of the cup.

rotate a disk in a direction it is not spinning: Go grab a plate, hold it horizontally in front of you. Imagine the plate represents the rotor blades and is spinning. Now tilt it left or right and away from you and towards you. Congratulations! You have now rotated the disk in a direction it is not spinning.

Short answer is conservation of angular momentum. Long answer is: Imagine you have a disk centered on the xy plane spinning clockwise when you look at it from above. This disk has what is known as a moment of inertia in the positive z direction (upwards). When you rotate the disk in a direction other than the way it is spinning you generate a force that is perpendicular to both the force you applied to rotate the disk and its moment of inertia. This is due to the conservation of angular momentum

Actually, that's incorrect.  First of all, the word is "precession", not "procession".  Secondly, the reason you release the sling at 90 degrees early has nothing to do with precession.  The projectile moving in a circle is moving in the direction you want it to fly when the sling (essentially the radius of the circle) is 90 degrees from pointing in that direction.  Releasing the sling at that point allows the projectile to continue moving in the correct direction, on a tangent from the circle.

Destin decorates with cats!  BTW Gyroscopic Procession can be seen in old slingshots that one would swing over the head.  You let go of one string when the projectile is pointed 90 deg from where you want it to go.

Here's how I look at it: To pitch forward (assuming this is a non-American helicopter that rotates clockwise) the increase in the bite BEGINS on the left side and the path of the blade continues upward as it spins towards the aft portion of the rotor disc. The disc actually pitches forward but, due to precession, requires the input be made to initiate it 90 degrees prior.

There are gyroscopic effects present but they cause secondary and territory effects - most importantly a flap back; i.e. tendency of the disc to go back to a position from before the control input - when flying a real helicopter if you apply forward cyclic to pitch forward the helicopter will pitch forward but then the disc will try to go backwards and helicopter will pitch backwards unless you apply MORE forward cyclic; but that effect is even more complicated to explain!

The complete opposite happens on the front of the disc; as the blade progressed on the left side the pitch is at the lowest value which causes the blade to flap down; it reaches it's lowest position on the front of the disc where we then have the lowest angle of attack which means less lift.

It has nothing to do with any gyroscopic effects;

What then happens, this induces the blade to flap upwards as it travels along the axis of rotation.  When the blade is on the back of the helicopter it's pitch is back to neutral but the blade has flapped up to it's maximum position.
And this is where the magic happens - if you would look at the flow of the air over the airfoil; by combining the up movement (flapping up) and the normal rotational movement the angle of attack of that blade increased which means the lift (and drag) is at maximimum

The flap up and down is important - let's start with the basics, the lift generated by the blade is not related to it's pitch angle but to it's angle of attack - angle between the airfoil chord line and the relative flow of air to the blade.
The 90 deg phase shift - let's imagine that we want to pitch the helicopter forward; on a clockwise disc rotating system (counter clock wise works the other way) the maximimum blade pitch angle will happen on the right.

Actually this video is 95% wrong! The 90deg blade pitch angle angle shift has nothing to do with any gyroscopic effects - it's related to the rotor head construction and design; in any rotor head system; be it fully articulated, semi rigid or rigid each blade (or part of it in composite system in a rigid head) can move freely in all 3 directions (without cyclic/collective input) - pitch, move back/forward on a lag hinge and most importantly flap up and down.

For the helicopter rotor, the problem is that one side of the rotor has an effective velocity=(omega)*r+V while the other is (omega)*r-V.

The former can get very high and later can get too low.

Brief explanation - looking from top of helicopter the blades are spinning counter clockwise causing its angular momentum (L) to be out the top of the helicopter. An upwards force is applied on the left side of the blades creates a torque coming out the front of the helicopter b/c torque = force cross radius from pivot point. Since torque also = dL/dt it must be in same direction as the change in L. Since the original is up & final is forward, helicopter roles forward to accommodate the torque.

Angular momentum is the "spinning inertia"; spinning things "want" to stay spinning; it doesn't have a direction, it has an axis of rotation. And torque is how much spinning force is being applied (or how much somthing is resisting the spinning force being applied to it); torque is why helicopters got tail rotors, they point sideways and off-center (way back instead of in the middle) to make the helicopter not spin out of control when it spins it's main rotor (action/opposite reaction).

If you're not familiar with angular momentum etc you won't get this: "the rate of change of the angular momentum equals the moment applied to the rotating body". In normal language: when you push the wheel with a force parallel with the axis (like Destin did), you produce a moment that lies in the plane of the wheel, pointing to the left or right. The angular momentum (=lies along axis of rotation) now CHANGES in that direction, that is, goes to the left or right, resulting in a sideways tilt.

In other words, drifting.

Imagine if you were to accelerate the rim of the wheel when you pressed it down. The portion of the disk that is moving down is also moving around. A tiny little time later, it is at right angles. So this may help if you know vectors... The initial angular momentum vector (spin axis) is straight up. The desired ang. mom. vector is pointed mostly up, but a little forward. The difference between those vectors is an ang. mom. vector pointed forward. So you want to torque about the forward-pointing axis of the 'copter. To torque about this axis, you apply more upward force on one side (let's say the left side) than on the other.

So for clarification, the whole "90 degree phase" difference thing is not really about preceding (in time) the desired tilting action (nobody claimed it was, I'm just tossing in).  It is about changing the angular momentum of the spinning blades (which is along the spin axis of the blades).  When a torque is applied to a body with angular momentum, the angular momentum changes direction (which is the spin axis) in a non-intuitive way. That's what Destin was showing with the wheel.

These forces are all independent of gravity, think 2001 a space odyssey. The room spins and it creates artificial "gravity".  Think that if each atom in the wheel wants to continue in a straight line unless acted upon by another force, then all of them together want to fly apart. These forces translate over the entire tire, and their combined momentum make the tire behave in this way, none of it has anything to do with gravity. (unless you REALLY get in the theory of relativity)

The "swash plate" moves a control arm connected to the blade to change the pitch 90* before the blade reaches the intended application of force. Meaning if I want to create lift on the 12 o'clock position on a spinning rotor. I have to tilt the swash plate so that the control arm moves and increases the blade pitch at the 9 o'clock position. Incidentally, on the 3 o'clock position the opposing control arm is decreasing the opposite blade's pitch to reduce lift at the 6 o'clock position.

As a continuation: applying an upward force to the side of the helicopter causes a lift orthogonal to the force because it changes the direction of the torque and therefore the angular momentum of the disk..
When the helicopter is hovering, angular momentum is upward, so torque is outward. When the rotation is disturbed, the angular momentum changes direction, and the change in torque, which determines the direction of lift changes.
